FacilityName: Cutrale Citrus Juices USA, Inc.- Dade City

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
POLICY SUMMARY

The Cutrale Citrus Juices USA, Inc. USA (Cutrale) Dade City facility (the Facility) is located at 38000 Cargill
Way, Dade City, Pasco County, Florida 33523. The Facility is a critical part of Cutrale's Florida citrus
processing operations. The Facility's main functions includes shipping and receiving blending juices from
oranges.

Cutrale is committed to operating this and other Cutrale facilities in a manner that is protective of the health and
safety of Cutrale and Contractor employees, the public, and the environment. In addition, Cutrale is committed
to operating this and other Cutrale facilities in full compliance with applicable Occupational Safety and Health
Administration (OSHA) and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulatory requirements.

To ensure that the Facility is operated in a safe manner and in compliance with applicable OSHA and EPA
regulations relevant to accidental release prevention, Cutrale has developed this integrated Process Safety
Management/Risk Management Plan (the Plan). Among the important components of this Plan are Cutrale's
system of policies and procedures for operation and maintenance of the Facility, and Cutrale's Emergency
Response Plan (ERP) for the Facility. Cutrale has designated its corporate Manager of Quality Process and
Environmental Compliance and the Facility's Director of Auburndale Operations as the individuals with primary
responsibility and accountability for seeing that this Plan and its associated components accurately reflect
Facility conditions and that it is fully implemented.

1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
POLICY SUMMARY

The Facility is designed to ship and receive juices from locally grown citrus fruits. These products are sold
directly to a reseller. To support these primary functions, the Facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system.

The refriger

ation system is relatively simple systems typical of those that are common throughout the food
processing industry. The basic technology involves the re-circulation of ammonia, with a change in state from
liquid to a liquid/gas mixture, then back to a liquid.

Ammonia is delivered to the Facility in its liquid state and is stored in a high-pressure receiver. From the high
pressure receiver, the liquid ammonia is moved by pressure to a re-circulator or accumulator (different
terminology indicating the same vessel, depending on the age of the vessel). Liquid is pumped from the recirculator
or moved by pressure from the accumulator to the individual pieces of cooling equipment, which
include chillers and air handlers serving production rooms, coolers, product storage tanks, and the like. As the
liquid pulls heat from the surroundings it begins to evaporate. Since evaporation (as well as condensation)
occurs at constant temperature, the result is a warm, low-pressure vapor where the liquid ammonia absorbs
heat and changes to a vapor or liquid vapor mix. The warmed, lower pressure, vapor or liquid vapor mix returns
to the re-circulator or accumulator where liquid and vapor is separated and just vapor is then pulled to a bank of
compressors. The compressor compresses the low pressure vapor to a high pressure vapor and is routed to
the condensers, which condense the ammonia to a high pressure liquid. This flow is then returned to the highpressure
receiver previously described.

To determine the maximum intended ammonia inventory, a complex calculation must be performed to account
for the quantity of ammonia in each of the major process vessels operating at their normal levels.

1.3 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has an aggressive accidental release prevention program that is based upon a foundation of
employee awareness and proactive system maintenance. This program is documented in this integrated Plan.
This program meets or ex

ceeds all requirements of applicable PSM/RMP regulations.

1.4 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In spite of the Facility's aggressive release prevention program, the Facility experienced one accident in its Five Year Accident History:

On January 9, 2012 at 10:35 a.m. the Dade City Facility experienced a vapor ammonia release from a 1 inch relief valve port on the Aseptic Re- circulator.  The operator was performing scheduled maintenance on the dual relief valve system when ammonia vapor started to release through the 1 inch port. The operator immediately closed the isolation valve stopping the ammonia leak. The estimated ammonia release was 34.9 lbs. One employee was sent to the hospital for a medical evaluation and then released. 

                 


1.5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility has an Emergency Response Plan that defines the sequence of actions to be taken by Facility
employees in the event of an accidental release of hazardous materials. This ERP has been communicated to
Pasco County Fire Service and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

It is Cutrale's policy with regard to emergency response that its personnel are trained to the Hazardous
Materials Technician Level. These are individuals who are likely to witness or discover a hazardous substance
release and who have been trained to initiate an emergency response sequence by notifying the proper
authorities of the release. These individuals also are trained to respond to a release by stopping the release,
thereby assuming a more aggressive role than those trained to the First Responder Awareness Level. The
ERP describes the conditions under which Cutrale personnel would assist the local responders in attempt to
stop a chemical release, as well as the sequence of actions that would be undertaken under those
circumstances.

It is Cutrale's policy for employees to call the Tank Farm Manager in the event of any release emergency. It is
the responsibility of the Tank F

arm Manager to call the Main Gate of the Dade City Business Center. The local
Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) Response Team has the responsibility to oversee mitigation of the release
conditions. Pasco County Fire Service, in conjunction with Cutrale, is presently responsible for determining
when evacuation of offsite areas is necessary, and for public notification.

1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

This Plan incorporates a number of modifications to Facility procedures designed to improve employee safety
awareness, enhance safe operation and maintenance of the ammonia systems, reduce the potential for
accidental releases to occur, and increase the speed and effectiveness of the Facility's response should a
release occur.
06/
